text: New from me, I talked to ex-Blizzard devs about the fraught development of Overwatch 2's story missions, why they've taken so long, and why some fear they might not come out at all.

Neither. I’m not expecting anything either way at this point. Merely trying to keep things in perspective that just because we all rightfully assume this isn’t happening doesn’t mean Blizzard isn’t still stringing everyone along.

It MIGHT still be. Things look bleak, but as sure as you might be that you know what's going on, conjecture and assumptions do not change reality. The vibes being off is not a company telling fans (and ex-employees, at this point) openly and honestly what's going on.

Something people embedded in a game need to keep in mind is that just because you pay enough attention to a game to see this as "writing on the wall," Blizzard has not publicly canceled OW2's story mode. Read the replies. People still think it's coming. twitter.com/OWCavalry/st...
If you're a current or former Blizzard employee and would like to talk about the development of Overwatch 2, I can be reached at kshepard@kotaku.com or 3477622601 on Signal and guarantee anonymity.

Loved reading this! I wish I shared your optimism, but I recently wrote about how the Persona games come from such a misogynistic and conservative place that I don’t think they’ll ever have their politics around women and queer people straightened out.

Wrote about Persona's messy history with queerness, and how small changes under new leadership in Persona 3 Reload made it more queer-friendly. For the first time, I'm hopeful this series might take the next step in Persona 6. Not holding my breath, but I'm holding onto hope.

The other website acting very normal about things they imagine I wrote instead of things I actually wrote again and one of the most exhausting parts of this job is the constant intellectual dishonesty directed at it and that’s very fun and cool.

I don’t know what the future holds, but I do know Kotaku has challenged me to be a better writer, but also kinder to myself as a worker in a capitalist hellscape. And I’m grateful to my coworkers past and present for creating an environment where I can slowly learn to do that.

And this first year’s been a lot of my established beats happening back to back. So in-between guiding the big games, I spent a lot of time really fleshing out select beats. Shoutout to gay stuff, Pokémon, BG3, and Overwatch for paying my bills.

After last year and the sleepless nights I had about what was happening at Fanbyte, I told myself I wanted my work to stop being the most important thing in my life, and somehow I lucked out in finding a job that has let me do that, even if part of me misses being The Newsie.

Despite the public shitshow with the TPTB, Kotaku has been…healing? It grinds against years of anxiety and self-served pressure pivoting from  generalist to essentially a beat reporter, but it’s helped with work/life balance issues I’ve had since I started writing about games.

It’s been a year since I accepted the Kotaku job. I did it through a swollen jaw, still banded shut, but I wanted the job, and I needed NYC. I was two weeks post-op and making plans to move away from everything I’d ever known in a month. My life changed and I could barely speak.

Weirdest thing? I’m still not used to being able to bite through pizza instead of whatever the fuck you call what my teeth did before. Was always a mess because my front teeth never actually made contact. You get so used to compensating that it’s bizarre when it works. Wild!

I made family swear to take no pics during recovery, so nobody saw when I looked like Binky from Arthur. But here’s the last pic of me pre-op, me ~2 months into recovery still swollen, and me now. I still smile the same, but all my shit finally fits together and doesn’t hurt.

A year ago I had double jaw surgery to fix an underbite and chronic pain. The timing sucked because I had to move to NYC while still swollen and barely able to speak. Recovery was one of the hardest things I’ve ever experienced. But now I’m in less pain, and am even hotter.

Between one of my full-time jobs erasing 1000+ pieces I wrote and the other laying off incredibly talented people because 🤷🏻‍♂️ it’s been a great few weeks for my self worth. So thank you to everyone who’s read my shit. The stray kind comment is all that keeps me going most days.

It's been a year since Fanbyte as we built it collapsed. I reflected a little on that experience, what was lost, and what can never be lost.

Post is public.

www.patreon.com/posts/its-be...

All things considered, still proud of what we accomplished. And glad that, for however long we were able, we made a website for people who don’t see their stories told or perspectives shown. We’re scattered now, but I know we’re all embodying that spirit wherever we are.

Nobody owes me anything, but if you'd like to help a queer creator this month, I'm a gay writer who writes about queerness in games and getting this off my back will let me keep doing my job that I love and in the city I've dreamt of. I just want to be able to move on from this.

Asking for help is embarrassing because I know this is an indictment of the American healthcare system. But, capitalism has drilled into my head that this is somehow my fault, as if the surgery wasn't necessary.  I'm still not even fully recovered and they're blowing my phone up.

I had surgery in November, then had to move to NY which drained my savings. Collections is on my ass and I'm just trying to pay rent. I hate asking for help, but I've tried to fix this myself and know that I can't. I'd appreciate any help y'all can offer.
